message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic deadband intermittent event-triggered strategy for formation control of multiple unmanned surface vehicles
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on the leaderless formation control of multiple unmanned surface vehicles (MUSVs) with external disturbances, communication interruptions, and model parametric uncertainties. Firstly, the auxiliary variables are introduced to transform MUSVs’ formation control into consensus achievement of these auxiliary variables. Then, to realize consensus of these auxiliary variables, the reference variables which can achieve the average consensus are defined based on the proposed dynamic deadband intermittent event-triggered mechanism (ETM). Superior to general dynamic ETMs, the proposed dynamic deadband ETM applies nonlinear coupled communication protocols and ensures the existence of positive minimum inter-event times (PMIET). Further, by guaranteeing the auxiliary variables superior tracking capability for the reference variables, the consensus of the auxiliary variables can be achieved. Thus, the desired formation is realized. Besides, the adaptive strategy and the radial basis function neural network (RBFNN) are utilized against external disturbances and dynamic uncertainties. Finally, through rigorous theoretical analysis and numerical simulations, the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method are effectively demonstrated.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, I found one relevant reference to event-triggered control:

Maurice Heemels was named Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

However, the search results primarily returned general information about event-driven architecture, event-driven programming, and time-triggered systems rather than detailed technical information about event-triggered control specifically.

Event-triggered control is a specialized field in control theory and systems engineering. Based on the reference found, it's a recognized academic discipline that deals with systems where control actions are triggered by specific events rather than executed at fixed time intervals (which would be time-triggered control). The research in this area involves analyzing and designing hybrid systems that operate in networked environments where control decisions are made in response to specific events occurring in the system.

If you're looking for more detailed technical information about event-triggered control systems, I'd recommend searching for academic literature or technical papers on the topic, as this is a specialized engineering field that may not be extensively covered in general encyclopedic sources.

Web search results for query: "Consensus"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Consensus democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_democracy"},{"title":"Consensus history - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_history"},{"title":"Consensus reality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_reality"},{"title":"Uniting for Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniting_for_Consensus"},{"title":"1992 Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus sequence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_sequence"},{"title":"Consensus clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_clustering"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of "Consensus":

## General Definition

Consensus usually refers to general agreement among a group of people or community.

## Key Applications

**Consensus Decision-Making**
Consensus is reached when everyone in the group assents to a decision (or almost everyone) even if some do not fully agree to or support all aspects of it.(no content)This practice originated from several nonviolent, direct action groups in the USA during the Civil rights, Peace and Women's movements in the 1960s, gained popularity in the 1970s through the anti-nuclear movement, and peaked in the early 1980s.

**Consensus Democracy**
Consensus democracy is the application of consensus decision-making to the legislative process, characterized by a decision-making structure that involves as broad a range of opinions as possible, unlike majoritarian systems where minority opinions can be ignored.

**Other Domains**

- **Computer Science**: In distributed computing, reaching consensus involves coordinating processes to agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

- **Biology**: In molecular biology, a consensus sequence is the calculated sequence of most frequent residues found at each position in a sequence alignment.

- **Philosophy**: Consensus reality is the generally agreed-upon version of reality within a community or society, shaped by shared experiences and understandings.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

An unmanned surface vehicle, unmanned surface vessel or uncrewed surface vessel (USV), colloquially called a drone boat, drone ship or sea drone, is a boat or ship that operates on the surface of the water without a crew.(no content)USVs operate with various levels of autonomy, from remote control to fully autonomous surface vehicles (ASV).

## Applications

USVs have a wide range of applications:

- **Commercial/Survey:** Non-renewable-powered USVs are a powerful tool for use in commercial hydrographic survey, and using a small USV in parallel to traditional survey vessels as a 'force-multiplier' can double survey coverage and reduce time on-site.

- **Scientific Research:** A saildrone is a type of uncrewed surface vehicle used primarily in oceans for data collection and are wind and solar powered and carry a suite of science sensors and navigational instruments.

- **Military:** Various nations have developed USVs for military purposes, including anti-submarine warfare, surveillance, and armed operations.

## Examples

Some notable USV projects include the DARPA Sea Hunter, an anti-submarine USV prototype launched in 2016, and the Protector unmanned surface vehicle developed by Israeli Rafael Advanced Defense Systems, which is the first operational combat USV in service.

Links: [{"title":"Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Radial basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Radial basis function kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_kernel"},{"title":"Radial basis function interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_interpolation"},{"title":"Talk:Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"File:4 Normalized radial basis functions.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:4_Normalized_radial_basis_functions.svg"},{"title":"Hierarchical RBF - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_RBF"},{"title":"Hyper basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Kansa method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansa_method"},{"title":"Thin plate spline - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thin_plate_spline"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about radial basis functions:

## Definition

In mathematics, a radial basis function (RBF) is a real-valued function whose value depends only on the distance between the input and some fixed point, either the origin. Functions that depend only on the distance from a center vector are radially symmetric about that vector, hence the name radial basis function.

## Applications

Radial basis functions are used to approximate functions and so can be used to discretize and numerically solve Partial Differential Equations (PDEs). Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.

RBFs are also used as a kernel in support vector classification, where the radial basis function kernel, or RBF kernel, is a popular kernel function used in various kernelized learning algorithms, and in particular, it is commonly used in support vector machine classification.

## Neural Networks

This approximation process can also be interpreted as a simple kind of neural network; this was the context in which they were originally applied to machine learning, in work by David Broomhead and David Lowe in 1988, which stemmed from Michael J. D. Powell's seminal research from 1977.

A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions, with the output of the network being a linear combination of radial basis functions of the inputs and neuron parameters.

## Historical Development

The first RBF based numerical method was developed in 1990 by E. J. Kansa.

## Search Results for "Adaptive Control"

Based on the web search, here are the key findings about adaptive control:

### Definition and Core Concept

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### How It Differs from Robust Control

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Technical Foundation

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

### Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

### Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

### Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

## Multi-Agent Systems - Search Results

Here's what I found about multi-agent systems:

**Definition and Overview:**
A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

**Key Characteristics:**
Agents in a multi-agent system have several important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

**Modern Developments:**
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

**Components and Agents:**
Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

**Applications:**
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

**Related Research Areas:**
Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Deadband control"

Links: [{"title":"Deadband - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadband"},{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Unmanned surface vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_surface_vehicle"},{"title":"Talk:Deadband - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Deadband"},{"title":"Dead-beat control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead-beat_control"},{"title":"Bang–bang control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bang%E2%80%93bang_control"},{"title":"Control Denied - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_Denied"},{"title":"Control (Mutemath song) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(Mutemath_song)"},{"title":"Control banding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_banding"},{"title":"Out-of-band control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Out-of-band_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about deadband control:

## Definition

A deadband (also known as a dead zone or neutral zone) is a band of input values in a control system or signal processing system where the output is zero (the output is 'dead' - no action occurs).

## How It Works

Deadband is the range in a process where no changes to output are made. In practical control applications, the controller holds its output steady if the change would be small (within the defined deadband range), and the calculated output must leave the deadband before the actual output will change.

## Key Differences from Hysteresis

Deadband is different from hysteresis. With hysteresis, there is no deadband and so the output is always in one direction or another.

## Practical Examples

A common example is found in temperature control: A thermostat which sets a single temperature and automatically controls both heating and cooling systems without a mode change exhibits a deadband range around the target temperature. The low end of the deadband is just above the temperature where the heating system turns on. The high end of the deadband is just below the temperature where the air-conditioning system starts.

Deadband is also used in other applications, such as leadscrews which generally have backlash and a deadband that must be taken into account when making position adjustments, and control can compensate for backlash by adding the deadband value to the position vector whenever direction is reversed.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, I can see that:
1. **Multi-agent system** - the paper deals with multiple USVs
2. **Deadband** - the paper uses dynamic deadband
3. **Consensus dynamics** - was mentioned in the search results

The paper's main novel contributions are:
